description.plain:
Busta Rhymes is a Grammy-nominated rapper, producer, and actor. Born Trevor George Smith, Jr. on May 20, 1972 in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, New York City, he would later move to Uniondale, Long Island but attended high school in Brooklyn with the likes of JAY-Z, The Notorious B.I.G., and Special Ed. Prior to his graduation from Uniondale High School in 1990, Busta joined Dinco D, Charlie Brown, and Cut Monitor Milo to from Leaders of the New School. The group opened for Public Enemy and their frontman Chuck D gave Chill-O-Ski the name Busta Rhymes after NFL wide receiver George “Buster” Rhymes.

Leaders of the New School released two albums, A Future Without a Past… (1991) and T.I.M.E. (The Inner Mind’s Eye) (1993), before splitting after an intense interview with Yo! MTV Raps. Busta’s popularity began to rise with his appearances on A Tribe Called Quest’s “Scenario” in 1991 and its remix in 1992, as well as the remix to Craig Mack’s “Flava in Ya Ear” in 1994.

This led to Busta releasing his platinum debut album The Coming in 1996, featuring the platinum single “Woo Hah!! Got You All in Check.” Busta’s subsequent four albums all went platinum, while It Ain’t Safe No More… and The Big Bang achieved gold status. He also released several international hits, including “Dangerous,” “What’s It Gonna Be?” with Janet Jackson, and “I Know What You Want” with Mariah Carey, as well as being featured on the #1 hits “Don’t Cha” with the Pussycat Dolls and “Look At Me Now” with Chris Brown and Lil Wayne.

Busta appeared in the movies Higher Learning, Halloween: Resurrection, and the remake of Shaft among others, and he also appeared in the fighting video game Def Jam Fight for NY.

songs.full_title: Calm Down by Busta Rhymes (Ft. Eminem)
songs.title: Calm Down

description.plain:
Busta Rhymes and Eminem come together for “Calm Down,” their third collaboration after their first in 2006 on Busta’s “I’ll Hurt You” and second later that year on Busta’s “Touch It (Remix 2.0).” In an interview with Rolling Stone, Busta described the track:

It’s a bare bones hip-hop, fundamental, boom-bap record. It’s samples, hard kicks, hard snares and a whole lot of fucking bars of rapping with both metaphors and punchlines. It’s a friendly reminder to today’s generation of what this whole thing is based on.

Busta went in-depth with HipHopDX and Complex about the process of making the song, which he says initially was a solo record but he wanted Eminem on the track, leading to approximately seven months of waiting and back-and-forth adjustments before the song was completed.

The trailer for “Calm Down”:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VRjLGRUyDoQ

Check The Annotated Cover Art Here!

songs.title: #TwerkIt

description.plain: “#TwerkIt” is a song by Busta Rhymes, featuring Nicki Minaj and produced by Pharrell. The song was originally promoted as as the lead single from Extinction Level Event 2, but the album took 7 more years to release, so it didn’t make the final tracklist. The song was originally billed as a remix to the solo version, but it was later repurposed as the official version. The official remix of the song was released at a later date, featuring Vybz Kartel, Ne-Yo, T.I., Jeremih & French Montana.

description.plain:
This song exemplifies the complex relationship between rap music and artists with religion– particularly the islam (as both Busta Rhymes and Q-Tip are muslim). In this song, rappers brag about their luxurious lifestyles filled with promiscuity, expensive jewelry, drugs and alcohol.These are things that one wouldn’t typically associate with a humble follower of God. Yet, according to the song’s hook, the artists clearly attribute their success, riches, and all the drugs, money and women in their lives to their “heavenly father” whom they thank for everything. This implies that today there is a more post-modern idea of what it is to be a christian and what type of personal relationship you can have with God. This sort of go-against-the-grain, quest for new ideas on religion, politics, and philosophy began during the time of the Enlightenment. As a result,religion has become more fluid thereby easier to accommodate in the lives of worshipers.

It is also interesting this is meeting of two veterans from two relatively new labels (YMCMB and G.O.O.D. Music) and they are both introduced by their bosses, Lil Wayne and Kanye West respectively. Busta stated that he wanted the collaboration to settle any rumours about beef between the YMCMB and G.O.O.D. Music camps.



The sample included in the hook and the instrumental of this song is from Alicia Myers' 1981 hit “I Want to Thank You”:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H_4wiLbsFnM

songs.full_title: Break Ya Neck by Busta Rhymes
songs.title: Break Ya Neck

description.plain:
“Break Ya Neck” is Busta’s first single from his 2001 album Genesis. The song was produced by Dr. Dre and Scott Storch, while the background vocals were done by Truth Hurts.  The “give it away” part of the song is interpolated from the Red Hot Chili Peppers song “Give It Away.”

A showcase for Busta’s ability to spit incredibly fast, “Break Ya Neck” is considered a landmark track for both Busta’s work and speed rap in general. Watsky even used the song’s instrumental for his breakout track, “Pale Kid Raps Fast”.

The general theme of this song goes along the lines of “if you haven’t broken a bone while listening to music, you’re not doing it right.”

songs.full_title: I'll Hurt You by Busta Rhymes (Ft. Eminem)
songs.title: I’ll Hurt You

description.plain:
Created in 2006, “I’ll Hurt You” was never released on an album by either Busta Rhymes or Eminem. The gem was produced by Scott Storch and Dr. Dre.

There are two versions of the track; later versions add sound effects and moved Eminem’s verse to the end of the song.

Eight years later, Busta Rhymes and Eminem collaborated again: “Calm Down.”

description.plain:
“Look Over Your Shoulders” is a collaboration between Kendrick Lamar, Busta Rhymes and Nikki.

The song samples The Jackson 5’s “I’ll Be There” and is said to have been created in April 2016.

The song was first teased in late-2017 when Music Mafia put the song up for auction. It leaked online on September 29, 2018; an alternate version with a different instrumental leaked on June 27, 2019.

In October 2020, a remastered version of the song was revealed to be the 19th track on Busta’s new album.

songs.full_title: I Know What You Want by Busta Rhymes (Ft. Flipmode Squad & Mariah Carey)
songs.title: I Know What You Want
songs.title_with_featured: I Know What You Want (Ft. Flipmode Squad & Mariah Carey)

description.plain:
“I Know What You Want” is Busta Rhymes‘ lead single from his sixth album It Ain’t Safe No More…. Northern California producer Rick Rock, known for his high-energy hyphy tracks, slows things down with this R&B track.

The track features Flipmode Squad members Spliff Star, Baby Cham, Rah Digga, and Rampage, and the song is a departure from their more hardcore collaborations such as “We Could Take It Outside” from Busta’s second album When Disaster Strikes. The track also features vocals from pop superstar Mariah Carey, and Busta talked about her involvement in the song during an interview with Rolling Stone:

I definitely thought Mariah was the perfect person for it. That was the initial idea. I just wanted her to add her sexiness to it. I didn’t want nothing over the top or nothing elaborate. I just wanted the right vibe and the right voice tone, the right feel and the right breathing — the right sexy overall feeling. She was perfect for that.

The single was an international hit, peaking at #3 on the US Billboard Hot 100 and remaining in the Top 40 for five months, while reaching the Top 5 on the pop charts in several countries, including the #1 spot in Hungary, Poland, and Romania. The single also achieved gold status in Australia and New Zealand.

description.plain: Busta Rhymes' bodyguard and entourage member, Israel Ramirez, was fatally shot outside the set of this song’s music video during filming in Brooklyn on February 5, 2006. The police have still not found a suspect. In the remix version video, the cheerleader scene is preceded by a slideshow of Israel “Izzy” Ramirez with a message from Busta Rhymes to the deceased telling him how much he meant to him and how he would not be forgotten.

songs.full_title: Put Your Hands Where My Eyes Could See by Busta Rhymes
songs.title: Put Your Hands Where My Eyes Could See
songs.title_with_featured: Put Your Hands Where My Eyes Could See

description.plain:
When Disaster Strikes… (1997) A thing to notice, is that busta rhymes uses the same rhyme scheme throughout the first verse, and then uses another rhyme sceme throughout the second verse.

In Complex Magazine’s internet series, ‘Magnum Opus’, Busta Rhymes explained his thought process for this song, and have a few interesting things to note.



Busta has stated that Bad Boy CEO Puffy  told him to relax, and that he didn’t need to yell on every song and that women don’t want to hear him yell all the time, also that people found his natural voice when spoken in a low tone sexy. This is why he raps that way on this record, and it’s the first record to feature this type of flow from him.

Also, him saying “Yo” after ever bar in the first verse comes from either the Haitian or Jamaicans (I can’t remember which) in Brooklyn. It was basically how they spoke, and Busta considered it cool.

songs.title: Why Stop Now

description.plain:
“Why Stop Now” is the second collaboration between Busta Rhymes with Chris Brown following their worldwide hit “Look At Me Now.” Even though it didn’t break through like “Look At Me Now,” “Why Stop Now” was a hit for weeks in many countries

Busta did it again; a perfect performance with fast verses including his gimmicks, and an unforgettable hook by his mate Chris.

songs.full_title: Touch It by Busta Rhymes
songs.title: Touch It

description.plain:
Busta’s flow on this song is very peculiar. As he makes clear throughout the song, and as the beat also says, this song is clearly a club track. Busta rhymes somewhat dumbs down his style then in order to make it fit. That is, when people are trying to dance and get some, they aren’t worried about internal rhymes and clever puns.

Busta, accordingly, keeps his rap style simple. All of his rhymes fall at the end of the line (check them for yourself.) He repeats the same rhythm from one bar to the next, for almost his entire verse. He also keeps the rhymes simple, only ever being 1 or 2 syllables long. Nowhere to be found are his signature crazy rhymes (“Yugoslavian and Czechoslovakian niggas be all into my bounce…”) Compare this verse to his GOAT one on “Scenario”, or even his later stuff like “Holla” or “Truck Volume” from the “Genesis” album, and they just don’t compare.

In fairness to Busta, though, “Touch It” is an example of the singular dynamic range of his rapping, using alternating loud and soft vocals to accent his flow, an ability he has demonstrated since his landmark appearance on “Scenario”. Interestingly, of all the featured guests on the various “Touch It” remixes, the only one who seems to fully appreciate and follow the formula is Eminem.

description.plain: The “Arab Money” remix features additional verses from Lil Wayne, Akon, T-Pain, Puff Daddy and Swizz Beatz. The song covers the topic of spending money like a sheik. Arabs are known for their ostentatious purchases such as luxury vehicles and exotic pets like tigers and lions.

songs.full_title: Woo Hah!! Got You All in Check by Busta Rhymes
songs.title: Woo Hah!! Got You All in Check
songs.title_with_featured: Woo Hah!! Got You All in Check

description.plain:
“Woo Hah!! Got You All In Check” was Busta’s debut hit single from his 1996 debut album, The Coming. A remix featuring Ol' Dirty Bastard was later released.

The single achieved platinum status after topping the Billboard Hot Rap Singles and Hot Dance Music/Maxi-Singles Sales charts and peaking at #8 on the Billboard Hot 100. The song was also nominated for a Grammy Award in the Best Solo Performance category in 1997.

The song’s backing track is partially sampled from Galt MacDermot’s “Space” and the “Woo-Hah! Got you all in check” line from the chorus is a callback to a Big Bank Hank line from Sugarhill Gang’s 1980 single “8th Wonder.”

Another awesome detail – look at each individual verse separately and you’ll see that every single line rhymes with any other line in its respective verse.

“Woo Hah!! Got You All In Check” was Busta’s debut hit single from his 1996 debut album, The Coming. A remix featuring Ol' Dirty Bastard was later released.

The single achieved platinum status after topping the Billboard Hot Rap Singles and Hot Dance Music/Maxi-Singles Sales charts and peaking at #8 on the Billboard Hot 100. The song was also nominated for a Grammy Award in the Best Solo Performance category in 1997.

The song’s backing track is partially sampled from Galt MacDermot’s “Space” and the “Woo-Hah! Got you all in check” line from the chorus is a callback to a Big Bank Hank line from Sugarhill Gang’s 1980 single “8th Wonder.”

Another awesome detail – look at each individual verse separately and you’ll see that every single line rhymes with any other line in its respective verse.

songs.full_title: Hello by Busta Rhymes (Ft. Chance the Rapper)
songs.title: Hello

description.plain:
Chance and Busta team up to give us “Hello.” This isn’t the first time Chance and Busta have worked together, the first time being on “Slip Slide,” off of Donnie Trumpet & The Social Experiment’s 2015 album Surf.

The song samples the beat from Luniz’s “I Got 5 On It” and interpolates the starting lyric from [Adele’s “Hello”.](https://genius.com/Adele-hello-lyrics]

songs.full_title: Dangerous by Busta Rhymes
songs.title: Dangerous

description.plain:
“Dangerous” is the second single from Busta Rhymes‘ second studio album When Disaster Strikes…. The song peaked at number 9 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and was nominated for the Grammy Award for Best Rap Solo Performance.



The chorus was inspired by the 1983 Long Island Regional Poison Control Council which was targeting the dangers of loose prescription medication. The Song also samples the Extra T’S 1982 hit song “E.T Boogie.” The song was also featured on the NBA2K15 Soundtrack which was curated by Pharell Williams.



The official music video created for the song is quite interesting and was directed by famous director Hype Williams. The film clip draws inspiration from Lethal Weapon.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iu-dxGdIkdQ

description.plain:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YYxzRYMrcVc
We Made It is a 2008 promotional single by Busta Rhymes and Linkin Park. It was the last Busta track released by Aftermath Entertainment. The song was supposed to be featured on Back on My BS, Busta’s 8th album, but since that album was released on a different label, Flipmode, the song was left out.

description.plain:
This song was a live remix of one of Busta Rhymes' most popular songs on the album “The Big Bang.”
It was performed live on BET on June 27th 2006. In this, Busta Rhymes collaborated with Mary J. Blige, Rah Digga, Missy Eliott, Lloyd Banks, Papoose, DMX and Eminem (Much to the audience’s surprise.)
This song contains samples from the popular song, “Technologic” by Daft Punk.
Here is the live performance:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BLcUdYQVsbY

songs.full_title: What's It Gonna Be?! by Busta Rhymes (Ft. Janet Jackson)
songs.title: What’s It Gonna Be?!
songs.title_with_featured: What's It Gonna Be?! (Ft. Janet Jackson)

description.plain: “What’s It Gonna Be?!” is a single from Busta Rhymes' E.L.E. album featuring Janet Jackson. This song is the first time Janet was ever a featured guest on a rapper’s single. The Hype Williams-directed music video with its then-state-of-the-art CGI effects reportedly cost Busta $2.4 million. The gambit paid off as the song reached #3 on the Pop charts, while topping both the R&B and Rap charts in 1999. It even earned them a Grammy nomination for Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group the following year. Janet would later include it on her 2009 compilation album Number Ones.

songs.full_title: Woo-Hah!! Got You All in Check (Remix) by Busta Rhymes (Ft. Ol' Dirty Bastard)
songs.title: Woo-Hah!! Got You All in Check (Remix)
songs.title_with_featured: Woo-Hah!! Got You All in Check (Remix) (Ft. Ol' Dirty Bastard)

description.plain:
A remix of Busta Rhymes' 1996 debut solo single, “Woo Hah!! Got You All in Check”, he returns with a slower variation of the original track and features his Elektra labelmate Ol' Dirty Bastard from the Wu-Tang Clan. Both rappers were renowned for their weirdness at the time, making this song particularly crazy and the location of the music video set in a psychiatric ward appropriate.

In a 1997 interview, Busta talked about the collaboration:

Ol' Dirty Bastard, he’s like one of the only artists that I see currently that tries to take it to the extreme. […] I always thought, ‘Yo, if me and him did something together, that shit’ll fuck everybody’s heads up. So I was just like, 'Boom! Let’s do the record.’ When we did the record, it was cool. But then when it was time to do the video, that just took it to the next level because now you’re able to see the two of us work together with your own eyes. The crazy, hectic, mad shit, you know’m'sayin'?!

songs.full_title: Poetic Justice by Busta Rhymes (Ft. Q-Tip)
songs.title: Poetic Justice

description.plain:
“Poetic Justice” is a track from the collaborative mixtape Catastrophic by Busta Rhymes' The Conglomerate. Given Busta Rhymes & Q-Tip’s long-standing fraternity, this track and subject matter were inevitable. They rhyme over Kendrick Lamar’s “Poetic Justice” that had just been released a scant couple months before this mixtape. Using a track which samples Janet Jackson’s “Any Time, Any Place,” the two friends spit verses about their professional experiences with Miss Jackson that weren’t too far off from their fantasies.

Busta Rhymes recounts the exhilaration of shooting a video with her for their hit collaboration “What’s It Gonna Be?!”



Although Q-Tip also worked on a #1 one song with Janet, his verse centers on his first experience with her, playing her boyfriend in the 1993 film Poetic Justice, the title of which, makes this song’s meta references go ‘round and 'round.

songs.title: Get It
songs.title_with_featured: Get It (Ft. Kelly Rowland & Missy Elliott)

description.plain:
“Get It” was announced by Missy Elliott on Twitter on January 31, 2018:

https://twitter.com/MissyElliott/status/958853907714895872?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw









Missy has rapped on tracks with Busta Rhymes before, including 1998’s “Get Contact.” Elliott  appeared with Kelly Rowland previously on Fantasia’s track “Without Me.”

Prior to “Get It,” Elliott’s last single as a solo artist, “I’m Better,” was released in January 2017.

Busta’s last single as the top-billed artist was “Girlfriend” which came out in August 2017.

description.plain:
“I Love My Bitch” (with the censored version being titled “I Love My Chick”) was the second single released from Busta’s first Aftermath project, The Big Bang.

It climbed to the eighth position in the UK music charts whilst in the US Billboard Top 100 it peaked at 41.

description.plain:
On this song Busta Rhymes recruits ‘political activist’ and Anti-Semetic conspiracy theorizer Louis Farrakhan.  Farrakhan is the current leader of The Nation Of Islam, a Southern Poverty Law Center designated hate group.
Farrakhan was also prominently featured on Jay Electronica and Jay-Z’s joint project “ A Written Testimony”

 The Southern Poverty Law Center description of Farrakhan is as follows,  “Louis Farrakhan heads the Nation of Islam, a group he has led since 1977 that is based on a somewhat bizarre and fundamentally anti-white theology. Farrakhan is an anti-Semite who routinely accuses Jews of manipulating the U.S. government and controlling the levers of world power.”

A collaboration between Busta Rhymes and the late Ol' Dirty Bastard.
